newsitem.title: INDIA: Gold-New India money policy seen sparking demand.
newsitem.headline: Gold-New India money policy seen sparking demand.

text.p: India's latest money policy, aimed at freeing frozen bank funds and cash in the hands of farmers, is likely to push up demand for gold in the Indian sub-continent in the near-term, dealers said on Monday.
Dealers in Dubai, the feeder market for gold imports into India and Pakistan, said the Gulf gold market will also get a shot in the arm from rising sub-continent demand.

On Saturday, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), in a bid to improve liquidity in the economy, allowed banks to pump nearly 85 billion rupees ($2.38 billion) into money markets over the next four months.
"Some of these funds will certainly come into the bullion market," said Makhanlal Damani, president of the Bombay Bullion Association.
Dealers said the RBI policy for the second half of fiscal 1996/97 (April/March) had also lifted credit controls on commodities such as sugar, cotton and oilseeds.
"The RBI policy has no direct bearing on gold and silver but it will improve the overall market sentiment," Damani said.
He said Indian demand for gold will go up, which need not necessarily push prices up as these depended mainly on international trends.
"But I can say that rising demand will take Indian gold consumption to more than 500 tonnes this year," Damani said.
The Indian policy coincided with the harvest of winter crops in India and Pakistan, resulting in increased money flows with the farmers in both countries.
Dealers in Karachi, Pakistan's chief commercial city, predicted gold prices would rise on higher demand from jewellers in the cotton-growing areas of the Punjab province.
"Gold demand from jewellers in Punjab is rising slightly due to the cotton harvest," one dealer said.
Demand for gold in India, the world's largest consumer of the yellow metal, is driven mainly by three factors -- wedding seasons, harvest and festivals.
On Monday, bullion markets across India were closed for Dassera, as the majority of the country's 900 million people celebrated a Hindu feast marking the victory of good over evil.
In the week to Saturday, gold prices rose 25 rupees per 10 grammes to 5,150 rupees on the Bombay bullion market.
Dealers say gold demand will get a fillip ahead of and during Diwali, the festival of lights, which falls on November 10 and 11.
"Gold buying is traditionally a part of festival glitter and rite," said Damani, adding that the winter wedding season in December would follow Diwali.
Dealers in Dubai, cheered by the Indian factors, on Sunday predicted a bullish outlook for gold in the business hub of the United Arab Emirates.
GOLD PRICES 24 CARATS PER 10 GRAMMES IN U.S. DOLLARS
(Conversion 1$=35.65 Indian rupees, 36.97 Pakistani rupees and 3.67 UAE Dirhams)
* Bombay and Karachi prices October 19 & 20 and Dubai prices October 20 & 13 respectively.
